cluster_relations.rel_desc: The origins of famous fairytales are intertwined with or framed in terms of folklore.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: origins not clearly documented; linked to folklore

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The Brothers Grimm collected a particular version of the Snow White tale.
The Evil Queen harbors jealousy, specifically the 'queen's jealousy.'

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: during the events of the story

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Ancient myths and stories related to Beauty and the Beast act as source material for the Beauty and the Beast fairytale.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: ancient myths and stories related to Beauty and the Beast
cluster_relations.subject_class_label: Beauty and the Beast Sources and Origins
cluster_relations.subject_class_group: Beauty and the Beast Context and Origins

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: ancient sources predating the literary fairytale
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: NarrativeRelation: earlier mythic narratives underpin later romantic fairytale

remarks: Both directions are kept to support different graph queries (source-of vs derived-from).

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The myth of Pygmalion and Galatea prefigures or functions as the earliest known version of the Beauty and the Beast narrative.

qualifiers.CausalHint: can be found in the works of Ovid
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ThematicLink: love and transformation, statue or beast becoming an ideal partner

remarks: Relation name chosen to capture that it is not a one-to-one retelling but an early form/influence.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject narrative or group of narratives has its origins or roots in the specified folkloric or cultural tradition.
args.justification: This relation expresses that the origins of famous fairytales are grounded in or arise from folklore, i.e., the tales' origins are located in a broader folkloric tradition rather than simply being loosely associated.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject collector or authorial figure gathers or records the specified story or tale.
args.justification: The Brothers Grimm are explicitly said to have collected a version of the Snow White tale, so the predicate should reflect an agent performing a collection/recording action on a narrative object.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject character experiences, feels, or harbors the specified emotion or emotional state.
args.justification: The Evil Queen is described as harboring jealousy, which is best modeled as a character experiencing a particular emotional state rather than a generic association.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject narrative or myth functions as a source, precursor, or formative influence for the specified later narrative.
args.justification: Both relations describe earlier myths or narratives (ancient myths related to Beauty and the Beast, and Pygmalion and Galatea) functioning as source material or early versions that prefigure the Beauty and the Beast tale; a unified predicate capturing narrative source/precursor semantics is appropriate.
args.remark: Covers both direct source and prefiguring/earliest-version influences within narrative traditions.

args.justification: All three relations concern how one narrative or tradition provides the origin, roots, or source for another narrative or its origins: either having origins in folklore or being earlier myths that underpin a later fairytale.
This relation models an agent (the Brothers Grimm) collecting or recording a story, which is a specific kind of collection action applied to textual or narrative items.
The relation links a character to an internal emotional condition (jealousy), which fits a class for mental or psychological state relations.
Origin and source relations in narrative contexts describe how earlier traditions or stories give rise to or causally underpin later tales or their origins.
The collection of a story by the Brothers Grimm is an intentional action carried out by an agent, fitting an agency-oriented relation group.
The relation encodes an internal emotional state (jealousy) experienced by a character, which is best categorized under a broad group for states or conditions rather than actions or composition.
